usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unapproved feature configuration increases security risks for the organization
threat.desc:
General threat description
Lack of security feature configuration exposes the organization to potential threats and vulnerabilities that may be exploited by attackers. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors could exploit misconfigured systems, unpatched software, or unsecured network connections to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data or compromise the integrity of the system. 
Impacts
The impacts of this threat include unauthorized access to sensitive information, data breaches, disruption of services, financial losses, and damage to the organization's reputation. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could exploit a misconfigured security feature to gain unauthorized access to a sensitive database, exfiltrate valuable data, and potentially sell it on the dark web. Alternatively, an unpatched system could be exploited through a known vulnerability, leading to a ransomware attack that disrupts operations and causes significant financial losses to the organization.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1584 - Compromise Infrastructure||ATLAS - AML.T0010 - AI Supply Chain Compromise

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Misconfigured Azure resources can lead to security vulnerabilities and breaches
threat.desc:
General threat description
Misconfigured Azure resources can lead to security vulnerabilities and increase the risk of unauthorized access, data breaches, and service disruptions. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers can exploit misconfigurations in Azure resources by leveraging automated tools to scan for weaknesses or by taking advantage of default settings or insecure configurations. 
Impacts
The impacts of misconfigurations in Azure resources can include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data exfiltration, service disruptions, compliance violations, and potential financial losses. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies a misconfigured storage account in Azure with public access enabled and is able to exfiltrate sensitive data. Another scenario involves an attacker exploiting a misconfigured network security group to gain unauthorized access to a virtual machine.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations||ATLAS - AML.T0049 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Customer-managed key (CMK) encryption risk mitigated by Azure services
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat involves unauthorized access to sensitive data at rest within Azure, on-premises, or Microsoft 365 environments. This threat exposes the data to potential theft or compromise, leading to compliance violations and loss of sensitive information. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
The threat agents could be malicious insiders, external attackers, or unauthorized users exploiting vulnerabilities or misconfigurations in the data storage and encryption mechanisms. Attack vectors include unauthorized access to encryption keys, bypassing data loss prevention controls, and exploiting insecure data handling processes. 
Impacts
The impact of this threat includes regulatory non-compliance, data breaches, reputational damage, financial loss, and legal consequences resulting from unauthorized access, disclosure, or theft of sensitive data. 
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to encryption keys stored insecurely, allowing them to decrypt and exfiltrate sensitive data from Azure storage services. 2. A malicious insider circumvents data loss prevention controls and exfiltrates sensitive data from Microsoft 365 environments, leading to a data breach and compliance violations. 3. Exploiting weak key management practices, an unauthorized user compromises encryption keys stored in Azure Key Vault, undermining the confidentiality and integrity of the encrypted data at rest.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1552 - Unsecured Credentials||ATLAS - AML.T0055 - Unsecured Credentials

threat.name: Unauthorized access attempt using embedded credentials in code or config files
threat.desc:
General threat description
The threat involves unauthorized access to the data plane and compromise of credentials and secrets, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized data manipulation. 

Threat agents/Attack vectors
The threat agents may include malicious actors, internal employees, or external attackers who attempt to exploit vulnerabilities in the application or infrastructure to gain unauthorized access. Attack vectors may involve phishing attacks, credential stuffing, or exploitation of misconfigured access controls. 

Impacts
The impacts may include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data exfiltration, data manipulation, and potential disruption of services. Additionally, there may be reputational damage, financial losses, and regulatory non-compliance. 

Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker utilizes a phishing campaign to acquire user credentials and gain unauthorized access to the data plane, potentially leading to data exfiltration or manipulation. Alternatively, an insider threat exploits local authentication methods to bypass Azure AD controls, compromising sensitive data and exposing the organization to substantial risk.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1552 - Unsecured Credentials||ATLAS - AML.T0012 - Valid Accounts

threat.name: Unauthorized access leading to sensitive data compromise
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to sensitive data and resources can lead to data breaches and information compromise. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized actors with or without insider knowledge may attempt to gain access through methods such as credential theft, social engineering, or exploiting vulnerabilities in the authentication process. 
Impacts
If successful, unauthorized access can lead to the compromise of sensitive data, unauthorized modification or deletion of resources, and potential compliance violations. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could attempt to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data stored in Azure Key Vault by stealing valid user credentials or exploiting vulnerabilities in the authentication process. By doing so, they could potentially retrieve secrets or access other critical resources.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1078 - Valid Accounts||ATLAS - AML.T0012 - Valid Accounts

threat.name: Unauthorized access through public network vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General threat description 

Public network access can lead to unauthorized access to resources, potential data breaches, and susceptibility to various cyber attacks. 

Threat agents/Attack vectors 

Threat agents can exploit open ports, weak network security configurations, and unsecured public network access to launch unauthorized access attempts, data exfiltration, or denial of service attacks. 

Impacts 

The impacts of unauthorized public network access include potential data breaches, unauthorized access to sensitive information, service disruption, and compromised system integrity. 

Example Attack Scenarios 

An attacker takes advantage of open ports and unsecured public network access to launch a brute force attack against the service, attempting to gain unauthorized access. Additionally, an attacker exploits weak network security configurations to intercept and exfiltrate sensitive data transmitted over the public network.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application||ATLAS - AML.T0006 - Active Scanning

threat.name: Unauthorized data access by Microsoft support personnel
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unauthorized access to sensitive data by internal or external entities poses a significant threat to the confidentiality and integrity of the organization's data and can lead to potential data breaches. 
Threat agents/Attack vectors
The threat agents can include malicious insiders, external attackers, or unauthorized individuals gaining access to local admin accounts. Attack vectors may involve compromised credentials, social engineering attacks, or exploitation of unsecured access points. 
Impacts
The impacts of unauthorized data access can result in data exfiltration, exposure of sensitive information, financial loss, reputational damage, and legal consequences for the organization. 
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker gains access to a local admin account with extensive privileges and uses it to exfiltrate sensitive customer data or intellectual property. Alternatively, a malicious insider abuses their access to view and potentially misuse sensitive data without appropriate oversight or approval.

countermeasure.name: Configure firewall rules for Azure Table Storage
countermeasure.desc:
Implement firewall rules for Azure Table Storage to restrict access to authorized IP addresses or subnets. By configuring these rules, you ensure that only trusted networks or systems can communicate with the storage account, effectively reducing the attack surface and preventing unauthorized access.

To achieve this, specify the allowed IP address ranges or virtual network subnets in the storage accounts firewall settings. This ensures that requests originating from unauthorized sources are denied, even if they have valid credentials. Firewall rules can be managed through the Azure portal, CLI, or API, providing flexibility for integration into automated deployment pipelines.

This control is crucial for protecting data from unauthorized access, especially when the storage account is accessible over the internet. Regularly review and update the firewall rules to accommodate changing network configurations or operational requirements.

For more information, refer to:

  • Microsoft Azure Firewall Documentation

countermeasure.name: Enable secure transfer for Azure Table Storage
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that secure transfer is enabled for Azure Table Storage to enforce encrypted communication for all data in transit. This setting mandates the use of HTTPS for all interactions between clients and the storage service, preventing data from being transmitted over unsecured protocols such as HTTP. When secure transfer is enabled, the data is encrypted using Transport Layer Security (TLS), protecting it against interception, eavesdropping, or tampering during transit. This is particularly important for sensitive or confidential information, as it ensures that unauthorized parties cannot access or modify the data while it is being transferred.

To implement this control, configure the Secure transfer required setting for your Azure Storage account and validate that all clients are using HTTPS endpoints. This is a critical step in reducing the risk of data breaches and complying with regulatory requirements that mandate the protection of data in transit. Additionally, ensure that any applications or services interacting with Azure Table Storage are updated to support HTTPS communication.

For detailed guidance, refer to:

  • Secure transfer required for Azure Storage

countermeasure.name: Integrate Azure Active Directory for Azure Table Storage authentication
countermeasure.desc:
Integrate Azure Active Directory (AAD) with Azure Table Storage to enable secure and scalable authentication. By leveraging AAD, you can manage access to your storage account using enterprise-grade identity and access management capabilities. This integration allows you to authenticate users and applications without relying on storage account keys or shared access signatures (SAS), reducing the risk of credential exposure or misuse.

To implement this control, configure role-based access control (RBAC) in Azure Active Directory to assign specific permissions to users, groups, or service principals. This approach ensures that access is granted based on the principle of least privilege, simplifying identity management and enhancing security. Integrating AAD also enables centralized monitoring and auditing of authentication events, supporting compliance with regulatory requirements.

For detailed implementation steps, refer to:

  • Azure Active Directory integration for Azure Storage

countermeasure.name: Use shared access signatures for granular access
countermeasure.desc:
Implement Shared Access Signatures (SAS) to provide fine-grained access control to specific resources in Azure Table Storage. SAS allows you to delegate access to your storage accounts tables, rows, or operations while defining precise permissions, such as read, write, or delete, and restricting access to specific time frames or IP addresses.

This approach ensures that only authorized users or services can perform the designated operations, minimizing the risk of unauthorized access or accidental modifications. Use service SAS for secure access from trusted applications or systems and user delegation SAS to integrate with Azure Active Directory for additional security. Regularly review and revoke unused SAS tokens to maintain control over resource access.

For detailed guidance, refer to:

  • Azure Shared Access Signature (SAS) Documentation

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Excessive access permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Excessive access permissions in Azure Table Storage occur when users or services are granted more access than necessary, such as administrative privileges for non-administrative users or overly permissive read/write access. This weakens security, increasing the risk of unauthorized access, data breaches, and misuse of sensitive data.

Threat Agents and Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers with stolen credentials, and misconfigured access control policies.
  • Attack Vectors:
    1. Misconfigured Azure RBAC policies granting excessive permissions.
    2. Overly permissive Shared Access Signatures (SAS) allowing unnecessary operations.
    3. Improper role and permission management leading to overprovisioned access.

Impacts

  1. Unauthorized Access: Unauthorized users can access or modify sensitive data.
  2. Data Leakage: Exposure of private or sensitive information.
  3. Service Disruptions: Accidental or intentional deletion of critical data.
  4. Regulatory Violations: Non-compliance with data protection laws like GDPR or HIPAA.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Excessive Read Permissions: A compromised developer account with read access to sensitive data leads to information theft.
  2. Excessive Write Permissions: Exploited vulnerabilities in a service with write access result in critical data deletion.
  3. Misconfigured SAS Permissions: SAS tokens with unnecessary delete permissions allow attackers to alter or delete data.
  4. Insider Threat: An employee abuses administrative privileges to extract sensitive data.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to data
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Unauthorized access to data in Azure Table Storage occurs when users or services access stored data without proper permissions. This can result from misconfigured access controls, compromised credentials, or overly permissive policies. Such access can expose sensitive information, compromise data integrity, and lead to regulatory violations.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers, compromised accounts.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting misconfigured RBAC roles, overly permissive Shared Access Signatures (SAS), or improperly managed access controls to gain unauthorized read, write, or delete access.

Impacts:

  • Data Breach: Sensitive or private data is exposed to unauthorized parties.
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Unauthorized users alter or delete critical information.
  • Service Disruption: Accidental or malicious actions disrupt availability or operations.
  • Regulatory Violations: Unauthorized access may breach compliance requirements like GDPR or HIPAA.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Misconfigured RBAC Policy: An overly broad RBAC role grants a user access to sensitive data tables, which is exploited by a compromised account.
  2. Overly Permissive SAS Token: A Shared Access Signature with read/write permissions is shared externally, allowing an attacker to modify or delete records.
  3. Compromised Insider Account: A malicious insider with admin access extracts sensitive customer information for personal gain.
  4. Privilege Escalation via Compromised Credentials: An attacker gains unauthorized access by escalating privileges through stolen credentials tied to an over-provisioned account.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1531 - Account Access Removal

threat.name: Unencrypted data transmission
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Unencrypted data transmission refers to the transfer of sensitive or confidential data over Azure Table Storage communication channels without adequate encryption. Without encryption, data transmitted between clients and servers can be intercepted, read, or modified by attackers, exposing sensitive information and undermining data integrity.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, and eavesdroppers.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting unencrypted communication channels (e.g., HTTP instead of HTTPS) to intercept or tamper with data in transit using techniques like packet sniffing or man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks.

Impacts:

  • Data Exposure: Sensitive data is visible to attackers during transmission.
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Attackers can alter transmitted data without detection.
  • Regulatory Violations: Non-encrypted transmission of sensitive data can lead to non-compliance with standards like GDPR, HIPAA, or PCI DSS.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. MITM Attack on Unsecured Channel: An attacker intercepts data transmitted over an HTTP connection between a client and Azure Table Storage, capturing sensitive information like customer records.
  2. Packet Sniffing on Public Networks: Data transmitted without encryption is intercepted by attackers monitoring traffic on public Wi-Fi networks.
  3. Modification of Data in Transit: An attacker intercepts and alters unencrypted data being transmitted to Azure Table Storage, compromising its integrity and leading to system malfunctions.
  4. Regulatory Breach: A financial organization transmits sensitive customer information without encryption, resulting in a compliance violation and penalties under GDPR or PCI DSS.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Insecure identity integration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Insecure identity integration refers to weak or improperly configured authentication and authorization mechanisms used to access Azure Table Storage. This may include misconfigured identity providers, reliance on shared credentials, or inadequate use of secure identity protocols. Such flaws can allow attackers to impersonate legitimate users, leading to unauthorized access and data compromise.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Threat Agents: Cybercriminals, malicious insiders, compromised third-party identity providers.
  • Attack Vectors: Exploiting weak integration with identity providers (e.g., improper configuration of Azure AD), using stolen or shared credentials, or bypassing multi-factor authentication due to weak policies.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers can gain access to Azure Table Storage by impersonating valid identities.
  • Data Breaches: Sensitive information is exposed to unauthorized individuals.
  • Service Disruption: Malicious actors can modify or delete critical data, affecting availability and functionality.
  • Compliance Violations: Failure to secure identity integration may lead to non-compliance with standards like GDPR or SOC 2.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. Misconfigured Azure AD Integration: An attacker exploits a misconfigured Azure AD setup to impersonate a service account with elevated privileges, accessing sensitive data.
  2. Shared Credentials Compromise: Multiple team members use shared credentials for accessing Azure Table Storage. If these credentials are leaked, an attacker can access the storage undetected.
  3. Weak MFA Policy: A lack of robust multi-factor authentication allows attackers to use stolen credentials to bypass authentication mechanisms and gain unauthorized access.
  4. Third-Party Identity Provider Exploit: A vulnerability in a third-party identity provider integrated with Azure Table Storage enables attackers to authenticate as legitimate users.

weakness.name: CWE-284

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

countermeasure.name: Configure sharing permissions to restrict access to authorized users
countermeasure.desc:
Set up sharing permissions in Microsoft Power BI to ensure that only authorized users can access specific reports and dashboards. To implement this, use the Power BI service to define sharing settings at the workspace, report, and dashboard levels. Restrict access by using specific email addresses, security groups, or distribution lists for sharing. Configure role-based access controls (RBAC) within the workspace to limit user permissions to "Viewer," "Contributor," or "Admin" based on their role. Regularly audit shared content to verify that access permissions align with current organizational policies. This control minimizes the risk of data leakage and ensures sensitive reports are only accessible to authorized individuals.

References

  • Power BI Security Overview

countermeasure.name: Define roles and rules for row-level security
countermeasure.desc:
Implement Row-Level Security (RLS) in Microsoft Power BI to restrict data access based on user roles, ensuring users can only view data pertinent to their responsibilities. Use the Power BI Desktop to define roles and create DAX filters that enforce data visibility at the row level. Publish the report to the Power BI service and assign roles to specific users or security groups. Regularly review and update RLS configurations to align with organizational changes and ensure compliance with data security policies. This approach minimizes the risk of unauthorized data access and enhances data governance.

References

  • Power BI Security White Paper

countermeasure.name: Ensure data encryption for Power BI storage
countermeasure.desc:
Enable encryption for all data stored in Microsoft Power BI to protect against unauthorized access. Power BI automatically encrypts data at rest using Microsoft-managed keys. To enhance security, organizations can enable customer-managed keys (CMKs) to control encryption processes. Configure and manage CMKs using Azure Key Vault and assign them to Power BI storage. Regularly rotate keys and monitor their usage to maintain encryption integrity. This control ensures that sensitive data remains confidential and complies with organizational and regulatory requirements.

References

countermeasure.name: Set up monitoring to track user activities and detect suspicious behavior
countermeasure.desc:
Configure monitoring in Microsoft Power BI to track user activities, access patterns, and report usage, ensuring timely detection and response to suspicious behavior. Enable audit logs in the Power BI admin portal to capture details about report views, data exports, and sharing activities. Integrate Power BI activity logs with Microsoft Sentinel or other SIEM solutions for advanced analysis and alerting. Set up automated alerts for anomalous behavior, such as unusual data access patterns or repeated failed login attempts. Regularly review activity logs to identify potential security incidents and refine monitoring rules to align with organizational policies.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized data access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unauthorized data access in Microsoft Power BI occurs when individuals gain access to reports, dashboards, or datasets without proper authorization. This can result from weak access controls, misconfigured sharing settings, or compromised accounts, leading to the exposure of sensitive business information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploit weak authentication or compromised accounts to access Power BI resources.
  • Insiders: Malicious or negligent employees accessing data beyond their role or need.
  • Misconfigured Permissions: Overly permissive or incorrect access configurations expose data to unauthorized users.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Exposure of confidential information such as financial reports or customer data.
  • Compliance Failures: Violations of data protection regulations like GDPR or HIPAA.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of customer and partner trust due to mishandling of sensitive information.
  • Financial Losses: Costs related to incident remediation, fines, and potential lawsuits.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Compromised Account Access: An attacker uses stolen credentials to access a Power BI workspace containing sensitive sales data.
  2. Excessive Permissions Misuse: An internal user with access to all datasets views confidential HR data they are not authorized to see.
  3. Misconfigured Sharing: A Power BI report containing proprietary analytics is shared with external users due to improperly configured sharing settings.

threat.name: Data leakage through sharing
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Data leakage through sharing occurs when sensitive Power BI reports or dashboards are shared with unauthorized users due to improper sharing configurations. This can result in the exposure of confidential or sensitive business information, violating privacy regulations and damaging organizational trust.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Internal Users: Employees or contractors accidentally or intentionally sharing data with unauthorized recipients.
  • External Attackers: Exploiting overly permissive sharing settings to gain access to shared data.
  • Misconfigured Settings: Inadequate controls over sharing permissions, leading to unintended data exposure.

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Confidential business information is accessed by unauthorized users.
  • Compliance Violations: Breaches of data protection regulations such as GDPR or HIPAA.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust from customers and partners due to exposed sensitive data.
  • Financial Losses: Costs associated with incident response, legal penalties, and remediation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unintended Sharing with External Users: An employee accidentally shares a report containing financial data with an external email address, exposing the organizations internal financial performance.
  2. Exploiting Public Links: An attacker gains access to a publicly shared Power BI dashboard that contains sensitive customer data due to improper access restrictions.
  3. Unauthorized Forwarding: An internal user forwards a shared link to a Power BI report to an unauthorized party, granting them access to sensitive information.

threat.name: Insecure data storage
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insecure data storage in Microsoft Power BI refers to sensitive data being stored without proper encryption or access controls. This can result in unauthorized access to critical business information, exposing the organization to data breaches, compliance violations, and reputational damage.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploit weak encryption or misconfigured storage to access sensitive data.
  • Insiders: Employees or contractors accessing unprotected data without proper authorization.
  • Misconfigured Systems: Improper setup of Power BI storage settings, leaving data unencrypted or accessible to unauthorized users.

Impacts

  • Data Breaches: Exposure of sensitive data such as financial reports, customer details, or proprietary analytics.
  • Compliance Failures: Violations of regulations like GDPR, CCPA, or HIPAA due to improper data protection.
  • Operational Disruptions: Alteration or corruption of unprotected data, affecting business decision-making.
  • Financial Losses: Costs associated with legal penalties, remediation, and loss of business.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unencrypted Storage Access: An attacker exploits weak security on Power BI storage and retrieves customer data that was not encrypted.
  2. Improper File Permissions: An internal user accesses confidential financial reports stored in Power BI due to misconfigured access controls.
  3. Data Exfiltration via Misconfigured Backup: Backup copies of Power BI reports stored in an unprotected location are accessed and exfiltrated by an unauthorized user.

threat.name: Insufficient monitoring and auditing
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insufficient monitoring and auditing in Microsoft Power BI refers to a lack of visibility into user activities, access patterns, and data interactions. This absence of oversight makes it difficult to detect unauthorized access, suspicious behaviors, or data misuse, increasing the risk of prolonged exposure to security threats.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External Attackers: Exploit the lack of monitoring to perform unauthorized actions undetected.
  • Insiders: Malicious or negligent employees misuse their access without being flagged.
  • Compromised Accounts: Hijacked accounts perform malicious actions without triggering alerts.

Impacts

  • Undetected Data Breaches: Prolonged unauthorized access to sensitive reports or dashboards.
  • Compliance Violations: Failure to meet regulatory requirements for activity tracking and reporting.
  • Operational Risks: Missed opportunities to identify and respond to anomalies, leading to data misuse or loss.
  • Reputational Damage: Loss of trust due to delayed responses to security incidents.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Undetected Unauthorized Access: An attacker gains access to a Power BI workspace using compromised credentials and exfiltrates sensitive reports without being detected due to lack of activity monitoring.
  2. Data Misuse by Insider: An employee with access to confidential dashboards downloads sensitive data and shares it externally without triggering any alerts.
  3. Delayed Breach Detection: Suspicious login attempts are ignored because audit logs are not enabled or monitored, allowing attackers to persist in the environment.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1101 - Security Support Provider

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-359
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-89
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection') The product constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS encryption for all connections
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that every client-to-database and inter-node communication is encrypted using robust TLS protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2/1.3), thereby mitigating risks such as eavesdropping and man-in-the-middle attacks. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate TLS configuration into the deployment process and enforce these settings via centralized management tools, ensuring that all data exchanged across the network remains confidential and tamper-proof.

Implementation Steps:

Enable TLS Encryption:

  • Configure the Other Data Store to require TLS for all incoming and outgoing connections by setting the appropriate parameters in the configuration files.

Configure Secure Cipher Suites:

  • Enforce the use of modern TLS versions (TLS 1.2 or TLS 1.3) and disable deprecated protocols and weak cipher suites to maintain strong encryption standards.

Manage Certificates Securely:

  • Utilize a centralized certificate management system to issue, renew, and revoke TLS certificates, ensuring that all certificates are valid and up-to-date.

Monitor and Audit TLS Usage:

  • Regularly review connection logs and perform security audits to verify that TLS encryption is properly enforced across all connections and to identify any potential misconfigurations.

References:

  • OWASP Transport Layer Protection Cheat Sheet

countermeasure.name: Harden configuration and restrict network access
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that the Other Data Store is securely configured and that network access is strictly limited, reducing the system's exposure to potential attacks. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate secure configuration practices into their deployment processes and enforce robust network access controls through firewalls, security groups, or network ACLs. This approach minimizes vulnerabilities, limits the attack surface, and prevents unauthorized access.

Implementation Steps:

Harden Configuration:

  • Disable Unnecessary Services and Features: Remove or disable default settings, services, and features that are not required for your operations to reduce potential points of exploitation.
  • Apply Patches and Updates: Regularly update the database software and its underlying components to incorporate the latest security patches and best practices.
  • Secure Default Settings: Replace default credentials and modify out-of-the-box configurations to adhere to your organization's security policies.

Restrict Network Access:

  • Configure Firewalls and Security Groups: Limit access to the Other Data Store by defining rules that only allow traffic from trusted IP addresses and required ports.
  • Implement Network Segmentation: Place the database in a dedicated subnet or virtual network segment to isolate it from untrusted networks.
  • Monitor and Audit Access: Regularly review access logs and network traffic to detect and respond to unauthorized connection attempts or misconfigurations.

References:

  • NIST Special Publication 800-123: Guide to General Server Security

countermeasure.name: Implement secure backup procedures with encryption and access controls
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that all backup processes for the Other Data Store are secure by encrypting backup data and restricting access to authorized personnel. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate secure backup procedures into the deployment and operational processes to safeguard data against unauthorized access, theft, or accidental loss.

Implementation Steps:

Automate and Schedule Secure Backups:

  • Configure automated backup jobs to run at regular intervals, ensuring data is consistently backed up without manual intervention.
  • Test backups periodically to verify data integrity and the effectiveness of restore procedures.

Encrypt Backup Data:

  • Encrypt Data at Rest: Use strong encryption standards (e.g., AES-256) to secure backup files stored on disk or in cloud storage.
  • Encrypt Data in Transit: Ensure backup data is encrypted during transmission using secure protocols (e.g., TLS) to prevent interception.

Enforce Access Controls:

  • Restrict Access: Implement Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) to limit backup access to authorized personnel only.
  • Audit Logging: Maintain logs of all backup operations and access attempts for traceability and forensic analysis.

Monitor and Manage Backup Security:

  • Utilize centralized management tools to enforce encryption policies and access controls consistently across backup environments.
  • Regularly review and audit backup configurations and access logs to detect and remediate any security anomalies.

References:

  • NIST Special Publication 800-171

countermeasure.name: Implement strong authentication and role-based access control
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that only authenticated users with appropriate permissions can access the Other Data Store. By combining strong authentication measures with role-based access control (RBAC), developers and DevOps engineers can effectively minimize the risk of unauthorized access and potential data breaches.

Implementation Steps:

Implement Strong Authentication:

  • Enforce Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): Require users to provide multiple forms of verification (e.g., password plus a one-time token) before granting access to the database.
  • Adopt Secure Authentication Protocols: Use industry-standard authentication protocols (e.g., OAuth 2.0, SAML, OpenID Connect) to securely manage user credentials.
  • Enforce Password Policies: Require strong, complex passwords and implement regular password updates to reduce the risk of compromise.

Establish Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):

  • Define User Roles and Permissions: Create clear roles (e.g., administrator, developer, auditor) and assign the minimum necessary permissions to each role based on the principle of least privilege.
  • Integrate with Centralized Identity Management: Utilize a centralized identity and access management (IAM) system to manage user accounts, roles, and permissions across environments.
  • Automate Role Assignment and Provisioning: Implement automation tools to streamline the assignment, modification, and revocation of roles, ensuring that access is promptly updated as roles change.

Monitor and Audit Access:

  • Log Authentication and Access Events: Capture and analyze logs for all authentication and access activities to identify suspicious behavior or potential breaches.
  • Perform Regular Audits: Periodically review role assignments and access logs to ensure compliance with the least privilege principle and to promptly address any anomalies.

References:

  • OWASP Authentication Cheat Sheet

countermeasure.name: Regularly update the database to the latest secure version
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that your database remains protected against known vulnerabilities by keeping it up-to-date with the latest security patches and software versions. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate a robust update management process into the deployment and operational workflows to ensure that the database software is regularly evaluated, tested, and upgraded as new versions become available.

Implementation Steps:

Monitor Vendor Releases:

  • Subscribe to vendor security advisories and release notes to stay informed about new patches and updates.

Test and Validate Updates:

  • Validate updates in a staging environment before deploying them to production to ensure compatibility and stability.

Automate the Update Process:

  • Use configuration management tools (e.g., Ansible, Puppet, Chef) to automate the patching process and enforce consistent update policies across environments.

Establish a Regular Update Schedule:

  • Define and adhere to a regular maintenance window for applying updates and patches, ensuring minimal disruption to operations.

Maintain Rollback Mechanisms:

  • Develop and test rollback procedures to quickly revert to a previous version in case an update introduces unexpected issues.

Monitor and Audit:

  • Log and review update activities regularly to ensure compliance with security policies and to identify any anomalies.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-40 Revision 3: Guide to Enterprise Patch Management Technologies

countermeasure.name: Use parameterized queries and validate inputs
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that the Other Data Store is protected against injection attacks, such as SQL injection, by enforcing the use of parameterized queries and rigorous input validation. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate these practices into their development workflows to ensure that user inputs are properly sanitized and handled as data rather than executable code.

Implementation Steps:

Use Parameterized Queries:

  • Implement Prepared Statements: Configure your database interactions to use prepared statements or parameterized queries, ensuring that user-supplied input is treated strictly as data.
  • Avoid String Concatenation: Do not construct SQL queries through string concatenation with user input, which can expose the system to injection attacks.

Validate Inputs:

  • Sanitize User Inputs: Validate and sanitize all incoming data against expected formats, lengths, and types using server-side validation techniques.
  • Apply Whitelisting: Use whitelisting approaches to allow only approved characters or patterns, thereby mitigating the risk of malicious input.

Test and Monitor:

  • Regular Code Reviews: Periodically review code to ensure adherence to safe query practices and input validation procedures.
  • Automate Security Testing: Integrate static and dynamic analysis tools to continuously assess and detect injection vulnerabilities.

References:

  • OWASP SQL Injection Prevention Cheat Sheet

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers exploit outdated vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Failure to regularly update the Other Database leaves known vulnerabilities unpatched, enabling attackers to exploit these weaknesses and compromise system security.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, hacktivists, and nation-state actors.
  • Vectors: Automated scans to detect outdated software, use of publicly available exploits, and leveraging SQL injection or remote code execution techniques.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized data access or data breaches.
  • System downtime or service disruption.
  • Compromise of data integrity and potential lateral movement within the network.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker uses an automated tool to scan for the database running an outdated version, then deploys a known exploit to execute remote code.
  2. A hacker exploits a known SQL injection vulnerability in an outdated system to extract sensitive customer data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers exploit misconfigurations in database settings
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Misconfigured database settingssuch as default credentials, improper access controls, or unsecured network endpointscan leave the system vulnerable, allowing attackers to gain unauthorized access, manipulate data, or disrupt services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, opportunistic hackers, and insider threats.
  • Vectors: Automated scans for default or weak configurations, brute force attacks on poorly secured accounts, and exploitation of unsecured network interfaces.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  • Data corruption or deletion.
  • Service disruptions and potential lateral movement within the network.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker identifies a database using default credentials and easily logs in to extract or alter data.
  2. A hacker exploits misconfigured network settings to bypass firewalls, gaining unauthorized administrative access to the database.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

threat.name: Attackers exfiltrate data due to insecure backup procedures
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Inadequate security measures in backup proceduressuch as lack of encryption and improper access controlscan expose sensitive data, allowing attackers to steal backup files and exfiltrate critical information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, insider threats, and state-sponsored actors.
  • Vectors: Exploiting unsecured cloud storage, misconfigured backup systems, or weak access controls to gain unauthorized access to backup data.

Impacts:

  • Exposure of sensitive and confidential data.
  • Financial, legal, and reputational damage.
  • Non-compliance with regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker scans for publicly accessible cloud storage buckets, discovers unencrypted backup files, and downloads sensitive customer data.
  2. An insider abuses lax access controls on backup repositories to copy and exfiltrate confidential business information.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service

threat.name: Attackers intercept data due to unencrypted communications
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
When communications between clients and the Other Database occur without encryption, data transmitted over the network is exposed. This makes it susceptible to interception by attackers who can capture sensitive information in transit.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, hacktivists, and state-sponsored actors.
  • Vectors: Utilizing packet sniffing tools on unencrypted networks, executing man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks, and exploiting unsecured Wi-Fi or legacy communication protocols.

Impacts:

  • Exposure of sensitive or confidential data.
  • Potential identity theft, financial loss, and privacy breaches.
  • Increased risk of subsequent attacks due to compromised credentials.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker intercepts unencrypted traffic on a public Wi-Fi network, capturing login credentials and personal data during a client-to-database transaction.
  2. A man-in-the-middle attack is executed on a system that uses unencrypted HTTP connections, allowing the attacker to modify or eavesdrop on critical communications.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access due to weak authentication
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Weak authentication mechanisms, such as the absence of multi-factor authentication, simple passwords, or outdated protocols, can enable attackers to bypass security controls and gain unauthorized access to the database. This compromises the integrity and confidentiality of the data stored.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, opportunistic hackers, and insider threats.
  • Vectors: Brute-force attacks, credential stuffing, social engineering, and exploitation of default or easily guessable credentials.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive or confidential data.
  • Data manipulation, exfiltration, or deletion.
  • Increased risk of lateral movement within the network and subsequent security breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker uses automated tools to perform a brute-force attack on a database account protected by a weak password, eventually gaining administrative access.
  2. A hacker leverages stolen credentials from a previous breach to access the database, exploiting the absence of multi-factor authentication to bypass security measures.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers exploit SQL injection vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
SQL injection vulnerabilities occur when user input is improperly sanitized, allowing attackers to inject malicious SQL code into queries. This can lead to unauthorized data access, data manipulation, or complete system compromise.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, opportunistic hackers, and script kiddies.
  • Vectors: Exploiting unsanitized input fields in web applications, abusing vulnerable API endpoints, and leveraging automated tools to identify and attack SQL injection flaws.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  • Data manipulation, deletion, or corruption.
  • Potential escalation of privileges and broader network compromise.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker inputs malicious SQL code into a web form that lacks proper sanitization, retrieving confidential customer records from the database.
  2. A hacker exploits a vulnerable API endpoint to inject SQL commands that alter or delete critical data, causing significant service disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application
